channel.title: Wikileaks
channel.description:
In case you've been living under a rock, Wikileaks is a website that uploads leaked information, mostly classified sensitive or secret, from 3rd party sources on the web. It is worth noting that none of that latest releases that have cause the media firestorm were classified top secret.
There have been discussions going on in the political front recently, mostly in the conservative party, about whether to classify the website as a terrorist organization for these releases, and it's founder as a terrorist.
There are arguments being made both for and against Wikileaks and I'd like to hear some opinions. I'll put in my bit to get started.
I think branding the organization as a terrorist one is far too extreme, as is branding Julian a terrorist and digging up dirt on the guy just to get him into custody.
1. The media would have us believe this guy is guilty of rape, but to make this clear, the allegation is that his condom broke during sex and he knew about it and decided not to tell his partner. Not only are they simply assuming he did this knowingly, but the charges came forward only after these women were dug up and interrogated. Not just that, but INTERPOL? For a condom? Come on.
2. The guy is only in trouble now because he ruffled the wrong feathers. He received international praise when he exposed extrajudicial assassinations and corruption in Kenya. A little fingerprint lifting by the United States is disclosed and everyone flips a lid and wants this guy dead.
3. Finally theres the rational part of my brain that says we SHOULD know what our own government is doing about foreign relations, especially after that last presidency. If we're calling the Prime Minister of France a thin skinned authoritarian, I want to know. If we're gunning down civilians from helicopters, I want to know. I should know when my government decides to steal biometric data from UN members. My reason says that if we're not doing anything wrong then we don't have anything to hide.
I can probably think of a few exceptions, but nothing that has been published on Wikileaks. Anyway... two cents? Anyone?

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: DrasarSalman
item.description:
According to media: Norwegian government is terrified for wikileaks because:

  • We got soldiers in Afghanistan using:
    ** Illegal names on vehicles (punisher).
    ** Viking helmets.
    ** Illegal marks on uniforms (skulls).
    ** Northern mythology sayings (til Valhall/to viking heaven)
  • A retarded prime minister and government.

Read full topic

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: gugamilare
item.description:
danielsangeo:

“The system is perfect.”
“Until you have a better solution…”

wat

I get I expressed badly when I said the current system is perfect.

The problem is not the system. Any system might work or fail, failure has nothing to do with republic, democratic, socialist, etc. The key, ladies and gentlemen, is humans. The problems have names and addresses. Whoever is in charge, I don’t care, but I do care about what this person does there.

The best thing about this internet war is that we are teaching them a lesson: they don’t have the power. I already said this.

Someonerandm:

What? Less than a sixth of one percent of the american population people support something? No!

Yes, in one day, without appearing on the TV, no posters with ladies in bikini about the site… the only kind of propaganda is the one that people themselves are spreading. If people are spreading, it means they care. In two days, half of a million people? That is a lot of people.

Someonerandm:

In any case, until a solution is provided, your complaints are worthlessly idealist. Feel free to complain, but it means nothing.

I am not a idealist and you are stubborn. How many times do I have to say: I don’t have the answer. Idealists are the ones that have answers, you have answers, not me.

Don’t you see that theorizing the best system simply does not work? Imagine everyone talking about one’s own idea. Theory does not work in humanity! What works is small changes to solve the problems that appear as they appear. Solving one problem at a time, we can slowly find the best solution for everyone.

Haven’t you seen History? Humans and more humans proposing so many perfect systems, they seemed so beautiful on paper, why did none of those work? Because they were perfect on paper! Therefore, stop looking for someone to present a perfect solution to substitute the entire system. That is impossible.

Now, you are suggesting that we stay still while they do whatever they want? Using political pressure to oppress freedom? Forget it, I won’t stay still. Staying still does not solve problems, instead it creates problems. If you want to deal with problems, face them! Don’t hide from them, they won’t disappear automatically.

If you want the solution, here it is: you observe, see what is the problem, you think a lot about the problem and then you do something. Then you think about what you did and wait for it to have effect. It requires patience. Don’t try to find a solution for everything, that is impossible, you have to take small steps fighting one problem at a time, one day at a time. The fighting has only began, don’t demand me to say how it is going to end, I’m not God!

Bradley had the courage of a lion to steal most of Wikileaks’ documents, he is in jail in the US and might even get killed for what he did. Assange had the courage to publish those documents. So, for God’s sake, grow some balls!

Fuskox:

How does the Espionage Act not apply? We don’t know exactly if any of the leaked documents are a threat to national security or interferes with any military action.

Innocent until proven otherwise, isn’t it? All the documents are carefully revised by various journals, as I said, to see if they don’t have anything that threatens national security.

Stop theorizing what could have happened and what might have happened and start using facts. Don’t say what you don’t know.

Fuskox:

And what about him receiving stolen goods? I saw no reply to that.

Wikileaks is like anything else in the press, they are allowed to receive stolen information, that is predicted in law. Wikileaks is just an online newspaper.

And stop giving so much credit to law, they are created by man. Unless you prove that they are harming people. And, believe me, if they end up harming people, even unintentionally, that will be used by their enemies like hell, so you don’t even have to bother looking for dangerous leaked information.

Read full topic

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: Someonerandm
item.description:
danielsangeo:

Reaganomics/“trickle-down” “voodoo economics” is a bankrupt economic theory (pun partially intended); as is Friedmanism. Keynesianism, which we haven’t had for DECADES, is the solution. Call me a communist, call me a socialist, call me a pie-in-the-sky, doe-eyed idealist…I don’t give a shit. And, by extension, the government.

Abraham Lincoln proclaimed that it was a government OF, BY, and FOR “the people”. A government of, by, and for politicians or business is not American at all.

How does that solve the problem? Also, never reference Abe Lincoln in reference to people’s rights when it comes to the health of the nation. Its not smart.

Read full topic

I wonder why Robert Novak didn’t get arrested…

Things that make you go hmmm…

Read full topic

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: Cameron_D
item.description:
Fuskox:

But wasn’t the video of the soldiers in the apache killing the press in Iraq on the site?

Its on the front page of the Wikileaks site, down the bottom.

Fuskox:

Didn’t that impede military operations?

Not AFAIK.

Fuskox:

Also, wasn’t it one military officer that gave him information, and he was arrested for it?

One guy (Bradley Manning) was arrested on suspicion or releasing the video, he is also suspected of leaking the Iraq and Afghanistan war logs.

Read full topic

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: Fuskox
item.description:
danielsangeo:

How does it apply? Please point the specific sections of the laws and his actions and justify it. Remember, you’re the one calling him guilty before a trial is done so YOU have to do the legwork here.

How does it apply?

To be honest, I read none of the leaks, I’m just running off what I’ve heard from people. But wasn’t the video of the soldiers in the apache killing the press in Iraq on the site? Didn’t that impede military operations? Also, wasn’t it one military officer that gave him information, and he was arrested for it?

Read full topic

Fuskox:

How does the Espionage Act not apply? We don’t know exactly if any of the leaked documents are a threat to national security or interferes with any military action.

Also, any documents of diplomats are inviolable, how does this not apply to any documents leaked. And what about him receiving stolen goods? I saw no reply to that.

How does it apply? Please point the specific sections of the laws and his actions and justify it. Remember, you’re the one calling him guilty before a trial is done so YOU have to do the legwork here.

How does it apply?

Read full topic

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: Acristoff
item.description:
They, being the military, willingly handed him the documents that’s the difference. I hope you know they haven’t published anything which has been a threat to national security, all names that have been published have not been harmed as a consequence. And I’m sure they know that publishing anything that is a threat that they will be hunted down like they did with Assange.

So at the moment direct harm to national security is not a threat that Wikileaks imposes.

Read full topic

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: Fuskox
item.description:
danielsangeo:

The Espionage Act does not apply to this situation.

Nor this.

Reaganomics/“trickle-down” “voodoo economics” is a bankrupt economic theory (pun partially intended); as is Friedmanism. Keynesianism, which we haven’t had for DECADES, is the solution. Call me a communist, call me a socialist, call me a pie-in-the-sky, doe-eyed idealist…I don’t give a shit. And, by extension, the government.

The fact of the matter is, the United States government (the best kind of governance there is) relies on an educated populace. If you hide things from people under the banner of “national security” that…well…isn’t, you don’t have an educated populace. You have corruption. I don’t care if it’s a Democrat, a Republican, an Independent, a communist, a socialist, a capitalist, a fascist or anything else.

Abraham Lincoln proclaimed that it was a government OF, BY, and FOR “the people”. A government of, by, and for politicians or business is not American at all.

How does the Espionage Act not apply? We don’t know exactly if any of the leaked documents are a threat to national security or interferes with any military action.

Also, any documents of diplomats are inviolable, how does this not apply to any documents leaked. And what about him receiving stolen goods? I saw no reply to that.

Read full topic

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: danielsangeo
item.description:
Fuskox:

What did he do that was illegal?

Well, he recieved stolen goods, which is illegal. Also, if you want to read a long block of text, here’s the Espionage Act of 1917.

The Espionage Act does not apply to this situation.

Also,

  1. His papers, correspondence and, except as provided in paragraph 3 of
    Article 31, his property, shall likewise enjoy inviolability.

That’s paragraph 2 of article 30 in the 1961 Vienna Convention of Diplomatic Relations, which is referring to the papers of a a diplomat.

Nor this.

Someonerandm:

No, I said the current system is the best of what I’ve heard. Please, share yours. If I disagree with it, so be it. At least it will give us something new to debate.

Reaganomics/“trickle-down” “voodoo economics” is a bankrupt economic theory (pun partially intended); as is Friedmanism. Keynesianism, which we haven’t had for DECADES, is the solution. Call me a communist, call me a socialist, call me a pie-in-the-sky, doe-eyed idealist…I don’t give a shit. And, by extension, the government.

The fact of the matter is, the United States government (the best kind of governance there is) relies on an educated populace. If you hide things from people under the banner of “national security” that…well…isn’t, you don’t have an educated populace. You have corruption. I don’t care if it’s a Democrat, a Republican, an Independent, a communist, a socialist, a capitalist, a fascist or anything else.

Abraham Lincoln proclaimed that it was a government OF, BY, and FOR “the people”. A government of, by, and for politicians or business is not American at all.

Read full topic

danielsangeo:

(Pssst…this is impossible.)

Did I say that I supported him? Also, innocent until proven guilty, y’know. What was illegal about what he did?

Just about as “retarded” as those that believe that any time we question what is made “secret” means that we don’t want the government to have ANY secrets.

Did he now?

Whoa, hold on here. Time out.

If he actually committed a crime, why didn’t they get him on THAT?

wat

What did he do that was illegal?

Well, he recieved stolen goods, which is illegal. Also, if you want to read a long block of text, here’s the Espionage Act of 1917.

Also,

  1. His papers, correspondence and, except as provided in paragraph 3 of
    Article 31, his property, shall likewise enjoy inviolability.

That’s paragraph 2 of article 30 in the 1961 Vienna Convention of Diplomatic Relations, which is referring to the papers of a a diplomat.

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: danielsangeo
item.description:
Fuskox:

When you have solutions that won’t work where everyone gets what they want, yeah, you will.

(Pssst…this is impossible.)

I still don’t understand why you support this guy. He leaks and publishes CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENTS, which is illegal, and you support him.

Did I say that I supported him? Also, innocent until proven guilty, y’know. What was illegal about what he did?

People that expect to know everything the government does are literally retarded.

Just about as “retarded” as those that believe that any time we question what is made “secret” means that we don’t want the government to have ANY secrets.

This man committed a crime, and should be punished for it.

Did he now?

I don’t know if he truly committed a sex crime, but the government had to pin it on him in order to get him for his other actions.

Whoa, hold on here. Time out.

If he actually committed a crime, why didn’t they get him on THAT?

I don’t see you crying out about people who murder others for revenge because it was right, so why should this man be set free because what he did was “right” in your eyes.

wat

Read full topic

danielsangeo:

“The system is perfect.”

wat

I do have a solution, but I’ll be labeled as a worthless idealist if I dare provide the solution.

When you have solutions that won’t work where everyone gets what they want, yeah, you will. I still don’t understand why you support this guy. He leaks and publishes CONFIDENTIAL DOCUMENTS, which is illegal, and you support him. People that expect to know everything the government does are literally retarded. This man committed a crime, and should be punished for it. I don’t know if he truly committed a sex crime, but the government had to pin it on him in order to get him for his other actions. I don’t see you crying out about people who murder others for revenge because it was right, so why should this man be set free because what he did was “right” in your eyes.

Oh, and Someonerandm is nowhere near alone with his views, I can vouch for that.

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: Someonerandm
item.description:
gugamilare:

I guess you are alone, Someonerandm

Honestly, the present system is perfect. In reality, Wikileaks and Assange have committed no crimes according to the law. No person have been injured so far, and all documents are seen by various leading newpapers to make sure publishing their content is not dangerous. So far so good

What? Less than a sixth of one percent of the american population people support something? No!

In any case, until a solution is provided, your complaints are worthlessly idealist. Feel free to complain, but it means nothing.

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: Wark
item.description:
Signed.

And Guga is right here.

The system we have IS the right system. And we need to maintain freedom of the press just as we always have and rely on journalists to expose corruption and immorality in government.

The problem is Someone doesn’t want to think we live under that system, and that freedom of the press doesn’t apply, and never did.

EDIT:
Wikileaks is back up.

https://www.wikileaks.ch
And Google has generously bumped SEVERAL of their direct IPs to the top of the search list.

LOL at their latest Twitter post too.

State department republishes Wikileaks’ doc. Will they now try to sue themselves? | https://fpc.state.gov/documents/organization/116764.pdf

Read full topic

item.title: Wikileaks
item.dc:creator: gugamilare
item.description:
Hey, people, a petition to stop the crackdown:

https://www.avaaz.org/en/wikileaks_petition/95.php?CLICKTF

It’s only been a little more than a day and there are 460 thousand signatures

I guess you are alone, Someonerandm

Someonerandm:

I just haven’t heard a better system from anyone. Once one is given, we can move on from our present system.

Honestly, the present system is perfect. In reality, Wikileaks and Assange have committed no crimes according to the law. No person have been injured so far, and all documents are seen by various leading newpapers to make sure publishing their content is not dangerous. So far so good
